greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Maximum divisor of n whose prime multiplicities are distinct (A130091).
comment: A number's prime multiplicities are also called its (unsorted) prime signature.
Every positive integer appears a finite number of times in the sequence; a prime p occurs 2^(PrimePi(p) - 1) times. - _David A. Corneth_, Sep 17 2019
link: David A. Corneth, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..10000
Gus Wiseman, Sequences counting and encoding certain classes of multisets
formula: a(A130091(n)) = n and a(A130092(n)) < n. - _Ivan N. Ianakiev_, Sep 17 2019
example: The divisors of 60 whose prime multiplicities are distinct are {1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 12, 20}, so a(60) = 20, the largest of these divisors.
program: (PARI) a(n) = {my(m = Map(), f = factor(n), res = 1); forstep(i = #f~, 1, -1, forstep(j = f[i, 2], 1, -1, if(!mapisdefined(m, j), mapput(m, j, j); res*=f[i, 1]^j; next(2)))); res} \\ _David A. Corneth_, Sep 17 2019
results.author: _Gus Wiseman_, Sep 16 2019
